prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: Section 430(1)[1] of the Criminal Code provides that mischief is committed by anyone who “destroys or alters data” or who “obstructs, interrupts or interferes with any person in the lawful use of data”. A property right in the physical expression of confidential information is required in order to bring a claim for mischief.

In the case of R. v. Turner,[2] the accused broke into data storage records and manipulated information such that the information could not be used. However, the accused did not physically copy or erase the tapes. The court held that, because the defendants had physically altered the computer tapes in a manner that reduced the owners' ability to use those tapes, they had significantly impaired the owners' enjoyment of the accumulated information. In this case, although the physical tapes were available, the accused were convicted of mischief because they had denied the victims the right to enjoy their physical property.
